source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: The irradiation growth behavior of annealed polycrystalline Zircaloy-2 has been investigated in the DIDO reactor at Harwell at fluences up to $1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 }$ neutrons $( \mathsf { n } ) \mathsf { m } ^ { - 2 }$ $( E \bar { > } 1 \ \mathbf { M e V } )$ and in the temperature range 513 to 673 K.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Growth strain data for two batches of rolled, annealed Zircaloy plate did not obey the $G \propto ( 1 - 3 f )$ EPY texture relationship with transverse direction specimens $\langle f = 0 . 2 5$ and $\mathnormal { f } = 0 . 3 5 )$ exhibiting negative growth following an initial positive transient.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: The effect of irradiation temperature on growth was not marked over the range studied except that, at $\yen 73\mathrm { ‰}$ , growth strains appeared to saturate at low fluences.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Apart from this, longitudinal and transverse growth strains decreased slightly with increasing temperature above $\$ 73\ 8$ .

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Specimens of large grained, $\beta$ -annealed Zircaloy with a completely random structure showed virtually no sensitivity of growth to either fluence or temperature under the conditions studied.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Previous studies of irradiation growth in annealed Zircaloy [1-5] have shown that the magnitude and direction of growth strains are dependent upon three main variables: crystallographic texture, fast neutron fluence (or displacement damage), and temperature.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: In fully recrystallized Zircaloy, other variables such as degree of cold work (or dislocation density) and grain shape, which have been shown to be important factors in the irradiation growth of cold-worked Zircaloy and zirconium-niobium alloys [1,3,6], are assumed to be relatively insignificant.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Much experimental data have shown that the growth rate of annealed Zircaloy gradually attenuates with increasing fast neutron fluence; up to at least 2 to $3 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 }$ neutrons (n) $\mathfrak { m } ^ { - 2 }$ $\mathbf { \chi } _ { E } > 1 \ \mathbf { M } \mathbf { e } \mathbf { V } )$ at $\$ 53\ 8$ [1,3].

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: The rate of attenuation has been shown to be much greater at $\Im \Im \mathrm { \bf ~ K }$ than at $\$ 53\ 8$ ; at the lower temperature, growth strains reached virtual saturation after $1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 4 }$ (n) $\mathfrak { m } ^ { - 2 }$ $( E > 1 \ \mathbf { M e V } )$ [2,3].

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: For annealed Zircaloy, the dependence of growth on temperature is weak in the range 523 to $6 1 6 ~ \mathrm { \bf K }$ [4].

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Adamson's data [4] show that, for material directions having an $f -$ factor ${ \approx } 0 . 3 3$ , positive growth is observed at $3 3 9 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ and negative growth at $\$ 55\ 8$ .

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Growth strains were predicted to diminish progressively as temperature increased above 573 K [10-12]

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: the EBR-II data of Adamson et al [5] contradict this assumption by showing a marked increase in growth strain with temperature in the range 654 to $7 1 8 \ \mathbf { K }$ .

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: The aim of the present work was to examine more closely the relationship between growth and crystallographic texture for annealed Zircaloy and to establish the effect of irradiation temperature on growth in the range 513 to $\bf { 6 7 3 ~ K }$ in the low-fluence thermal reactor regime.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: At this stage, fluences of only $\mathord { \simeq } 1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 }$ (n) $\mathfrak { m } ^ { - 2 }$ $( E > 1 \ \mathbf { M e V } )$ have been achieved

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Fully recrystallized Zircaloy-2 specimens were manufactured from two batches of annealed, rolled plate (Types A and B) and from a batch of material with an as-cast $\beta$ -structure (Type C).

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk1
evidence_span: Microstructures of Materials A and B comprised equiaxed grains of mean diameters 45 and $3 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ , respectively.

evidence_span: growth of annealed Zircaloy is not influenced markedly by irradiation temperature in the range 513 to 673 K

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk5

evidence_span: At 353 K, breakaway was delayed to a slightly greater fluence

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: Growth strain measurements on annealed polycrystalline Zircaloy-2 have been made after irradiation in the DIDO reactor to fluences up to $1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 }$ (n) $\mathfrak { m } ^ { - 2 }$ $E > 1 \ \mathbf { M e V } )$ in the temperature range 513 to $\bf { 6 7 3 ~ K }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: Except at $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ , growth strains did not obey the widely used $G \alpha ( 1 \mathrm { ~ - ~ }$ $3 f )$ texture relationship: material with $\mathnormal { f } = 0 . 2 5$ exhibited negative growth.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: material with $\mathnormal { f } = 0 . 2 5$ exhibited negative growth.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: At all temperatures the transverse plate specimens, with $f$ -factors 0.25 and 0.35, underwent an initial positive growth transient before contracting at higher fluences.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: At all temperatures the transverse plate specimens, with $f$ -factors 0.25 and 0.35, underwent an initial positive growth transient before contracting at higher fluences.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: Growth strains at a fluence of $1 \dot { \times } \dot { 1 } 0 ^ { 2 5 } ( \mathfrak { n } ) \mathfrak { m } ^ { - 2 }$ $E > 1 \mathrm { \bf ~ M e V } )$ decreased with increasing irradiation temperature above 573 K in both longitudinal and transverse directions.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: At 673 K the growth rate attenuates more rapidly than at the lower irradiation temperatures.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: Growth experiments have been performed up to a fast neutron dose of $\pmb { 4 . 2 . 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } }$ neutrons $( { \boldsymbol { \mathsf { n } } } ) / { \mathsf { m } } ^ { 2 }$ on polycrystalline iodide zirconium specimens of differing texture, grain size, and dislocation densities at 353 and $\$ 53\textbf { K }$
specimen_state: polycrystalline, differing texture, grain size, and dislocation densities

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: Rapid attenuation of growth occurs in annealed material above a dose of $6 . 1 0 ^ { 2 4 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ at $3 5 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: only weak dose and texture dependences of growth are observed in similar material at $\$ 53\ 8$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: solute tin atom trapping is effective in enhancing low dose growth followed by rapid growth saturation at $\Im \Im \mathrm { \textbf { K } }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_027_chunk6
evidence_span: The importance of a preexisting dislocation structure in permitting growth to continue unattenuated with dose at $\Im \Im \mathrm { \textbf { K } }$ is shown in growth data obtained on as-received coldworked iodide zirconium.
